segments.text: This is an interview with Mary Miller.
The date is April 11th, 1985.
What is your maiden name and your entire name, please?
And how old were you during the years of 1940 to 1945?
And where were you in those same years, 1940, 1945?
I was in Marseille part of the time, and then we moved to Nice.
How long after France fell to the Nazis in 1940 was it before you became involved with the resistance?
Well, I wasn't really involved very much with the resistance, but you might say that around 1943 we had a closer encounter.
And what was this?
Well, my brother and myself were living in a hotel very close to the Germans where the Gestapo was located.
And the resistance was all around us.
We were very much aware of what was going on, but I didn't actually participate in it, but my brother did.
Okay.
Did any of the roles that you had during that time, 1940, 1945, change as you went along?
You said you were very close to all of what was going on in the resistance in Nice.
Did you know about heads of resistance, people that were in the resistance?
Do you know any names of people in that area that were in the resistance?

Jean Médecin were very much in charge of the resistance and there were a lot of professors throughout these days in town and we didn't have any particular names that we could mention but we knew that all these people were working for the resistance.
Everybody who was interested in getting rid of the Germans was involved in the resistance
while then occupying my mother's hotel at that time in 1943.
Did you ever talk with the rest of your family about what they did in the resistance, what close friends or other family members did in the resistance?

uh in one way we were trying to resist which was more or less an intellectual approach to it some of my teachers were writing poetry and literature and this was distributed throughout the city it was most of the time poking fun at the germans and trying to bring hope to the
to the people about better days.
And it was sort of underground kind of literature, but it was very necessary for the morale of the people.
So this was one way that we were showing that we still had a little bit of hope and pride, and we weren't really losing the war.
We were just temporarily
You said you used a lot of literature and stuff.
Was that ever used as a mode for a code for delivering messages or anything that you know of?
There were messages that were delivered every day, and you could hear them on the radio in the morning.
Even though it was jammed by the Germans, you could hear the radio messages going out.
You said your brother did some stuff.
Did you do any particular things before you ended up going to the boarding school?
But the one thing we did, my mother and myself and my brother, was to hide the Jewish people who were being persecuted by the Germans.
So in that sense we were doing a little bit of work for the non-citizens.
But it wasn't very much of a tragedy to have
from one day to the next, they could disappear, and they put in the trucks that were taking off for Auschwitz.
And so we brought food to them, we hid them in the cellars, and we brought food to them, and we could have been in trouble had we been found out by the Germans, because it was a very serious matter.
Did you have special codes among each other when you hid these people, the Jews?
Did you have special ways that you could know that somebody else was sensitive to that?
So did you have a code name in particular?
Did anyone in your family?
No.
Okay.
Did you know that D-Day was coming at all?

like Nice was so close to the Italian border and so much in the south of France that they were never going to arrive, although we could hear on the radio every day the progress that they were making in the north and the central part of France, how they were becoming liberated.
But Nice always seemed to be so far away, and we kept waiting.
And the underground had been advised by the Allies,
not to do anything to liberate the city, to wait for the Americans.
But they finally got grown, became very desperate, and they decided to take matters in their own hands.
And the young people of the underground are the ones who actually liberated these.
And when the Americans arrived, it had already been liberated.
Did you participate in this?
Did you know of any specific incidences that friends of yours maybe participated in?
Well, no, I didn't.
Not really.
Okay.
But they were really told not to do anything about liberating the town.
Okay.
Were you aware of all the jobs that the resistance was doing, the intelligence, the transportation, what you helped with, hiding the Jews and moving them?
Were you aware of all that was going on?
We had, very close to our hotel, there was a house where the Gestapo used and the Nazis used to gather the Jewish people before they were put in the trucks and sent out to the railroad stations.

sent to Auschwitz and these poor people were gathered in this one place and it was awful because you could hear them singing to keep courage and you could sometimes hear children crying and it was just a tragedy and we were all aware of what was going on and it was difficult, you know.
Yeah.
Were you aware of the ongoing arrests and execution of resistance members?
I know you said you didn't do a lot, but y'all did hide the Jews, and that was, as you've already hinted at, punishable by the Germans.
Were you aware of all the arrests and executions that were going on?
And if so, how did you handle your own danger or your family's danger?
and we didn't worry about the tension.
We did know that they were, we couldn't even speak very, you know, outside because there were Nazi Gestapos all around that were wearing civilian clothes, and we were extremely cautious.
But they made certainly no bones about what they would do to anybody if they actually caught them doing something.

As a matter of fact, the most awful experience that we had, my brother and I, was walking down the main street and watching those two young men being hung in the pillars of the main street because they had been discovered to do underground work.
And it was a terrible tragedy to see
I can imagine.

Did you, any member of your families, or anyone that you know, have, oh, I guess you could call them psychiatric problems during or after World War II, such as nervous breakdowns or continuous nightmares?
were involved with the Germans.
Some of the prostitutes, say, and some of the people who collaborated with the Germans had been all observed by the people of Nice, and they were punished.
What they did is they loaded them up and put them in a... Well, first of all, they grabbed them and shaved their heads completely.
And women were completely bald.
And then they marked them in some way, and they put them in those large trucks, and they paraded them all through the city of Nice.
So you can imagine that must have made a terrible effect on these people, and they probably
Yeah, I would imagine.
You've already mentioned the house that was close to the hotel you were in that they put the Jews in before they went off to the concentration camps.
Were there any specific raids where the Nazis actually gathered up the people that you knew?
Well, yes.
As a matter of fact, one day on my birthday, I went next door to borrow a record carrier
I didn't even know that, you know, I didn't even think that it was Jewish.
I was just going to go, a record player.
And when I walked in there with my friend, I realized that the gate was open to the garden.
So we walked through there, and then we went to the front door, and we rang the bell, thinking my friend was going to answer it.
But the Gestapo answered the door.
And we started moving away, but they insisted that we come in.
So this friend and myself walked in there, a little bit shaky, not knowing what was going to happen to us.
And then they put us in a room because they didn't speak any French.
And then they said that we should sit still and wait for the officer who spoke French to come over and talk to us.
And we sat there, my friend and I, a little bit scared.
for about 15 minutes, and finally this officer came with a great stature and started asking us if we were Jewish.
And we said no, we weren't Jewish.
We were just friends and people.
And so he took us over into the living room, and this German man started slapping the Jewish man who was sitting in an armchair.

and he had already been abused and he was in terrible shape and this German officer pointed out to the Jewish bread and the Jewish wine and the Jewish business Jewish that telling us that everything in this house was Jewish and this one was Jewish and were we Jewish we kept saying no we weren't Jewish and
they said, okay, they took my friend who was a male and they said, go and check him, take his clothes off and see whether he's been circumcised.
Because I guess in those days, you know, it was proof that they needed to be circumcised.
And so, after a while, they put us back into the room and we kept waiting to know what was going to happen to us.
We said, can we please go back to

my house and they said well we let you go back but under one condition and it is that you say nothing nothing to anybody that we're here so we were finally released and we went back to the hotel and that was the end of that we were very scared and everybody thought we had been on some jump somewhere but
His son, who fortunately had gone to a football game, escaped because the neighbors, as soon as he came home, advised him that the Gestapo was in his home.
And he was sheltered in the neighbor's home, another neighbor of mine.
And he was given some clothes, and he was sent to another city, and he changed his name.
But I think that a few months later, we didn't hear from him anymore.
Did you ever find out what happened to your friend?
No, we didn't because he had sent us a couple of letters when he first arrived to Lyon, the other city that he went to, and as I say, changed his name, and we received two letters.
I read quite a bit about the French police sometimes even seem to be aiding the Nazis.
Were you ever questioned or harassed by the French police?
Did it ever seem to you that they were trying to help the Nazis, maybe not by choice, but out of situation, they had to comply with what the Nazis were telling them?
Did anyone ever seem to go against that?
Did they get upset with that?
Oh, yes, of course they did.
But, you know, you had to play your part, right?
You had to walk the middle of the road.
You had to be very careful.
You've already said you were questioned.
Were any other members of your family ever questioned, maybe your mother or your brother?

and that we were collaborating and we were playing, you know, and they even threatened to confiscate the radio from us because it was against their courage to try and find out what was really happening.
And we kept saying, oh, no, we don't listen to the BBC.
But one day we got tired of that.
We said, OK, we're listening to the BBC.
And you may as well hear that the war is being lost by you and that the Americans are coming to liberate us.
And they were very shocked by that.
But from that day on, they kept asking us because they didn't
You seem very much to live where a bunch of Germans were.
All we think of when we think of the Nazis are more like the Gestapo type Nazi.
Can you tell me a little bit about the German people that were there as German soldiers?
like they felt sorry for my little brother, who was so small and skinny.
And one of the fellows kept asking him to come up to his room, and he would share his own lashes with my brother.
But then on the other hand, they were the other breed
And they were very ugly.
They wouldn't let us use our dining room.
And the maid would come downstairs, my mother's maid, and say, well, the first group of Germans used to give us leftover soup.
Do you have any leftover?
Because we need it.
Don't throw it away.
And they would say, no, we don't have any.
They would never give us any.
And we would actually see them throw it away.
About what percentage of the population in your area do you think were members of the resistance?
You knew about it, but you didn't know individuals, or did you know the individuals?
We knew them by, we could see them go back and forth, but we didn't know them by name.
There was no such thing as knowing them by name, you know, because they were all, you know, people that we never knew before anyway.
Where did they come from?
They were refugees from the northern part, or...?
the professors, they were lawyers, they were all kinds of people.
And one of the, I think, most prominent is the one whose family has been defective
And do you know any people that continued from the resistance and, like you said, are now continuing to be prominent?
Well, I've asked some pretty specific questions.
Are there any things that you have, in particular your feelings about,
World War II in general, or the invasion of the Nazis, or the Jews, anything that the French did in the resistance.
Are there specific things that you would like to mention?
Well, it was a pretty grim time, and I was young, and it was pretty astounding that we had to, you know, it was wartime, and we knew that the Germans were bad people, and we
We knew that it wouldn't last, but we had to abide by the curfew.
We had to...
It was grim to see that our young men were being taken and sent over to Germany to make arms, to make more arms, or that our Jewish people were being persecuted.
And it was really sad times for us.
And to see our cities
you know, being invaded by those troops walking up and down, yelling their songs, military songs.
It was really a chilling experience.

atrocities they did when they would take a machine gun in some of the country roads and would see a bunch of little girls come out of their church in their First Communion outfits and they would machine gun all these little girls.
Atrocities like this went on all over France and it was a very bad period.
Well, I think that's about all the questions I have.
Anything else that you'd like to add?
and we had a good sense of humor which helped us, you know, weather this storm and we were very proud of our young people.
I was very proud of my own brother because of what he did by concealing and stealing those weapons and passing them out to the underground.
My mother and I and myself were extremely
surprised after the armistice to be invited to a very formal ceremony and to see my little brother step forward and be given a marvelous shiny medal.
We didn't know why the medal was given to him, simply because he had been smuggling arms to the underground all these months.
So you didn't know at the time that he was doing that?
Well, I certainly appreciate the interview, and thank you very much.
Let me see.
You say there's one more episode with you and your brother playing tricks on the Germans?
Well, go ahead.
military marches, troops, and they were reporting to some kind of a base of activity.
And we could tell them to come regularly.
And so we decided that we would say some tricks on them.
And it was at nighttime, and we knew they were coming up.
And we, my brother and I, went to a street corner where we knew they were always turning.
And we changed the street sign.

They were marching around and they stopped around and the officer would flash his flashlight on the street sign and then he would see, oh, we must go in that direction and they would all march off into the wrong direction.
And my brother and I would just giggle and laugh.
See, that was a great story.
I would say so.
Well, again, thank you very much for this interview.
